facts.text: These are four appeals with special leave under article 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. These are four appeals with special leave under article 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 652 of 1957 and 654 of 1957 are against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta declining to call for a statement of the case from the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Two of these appeals, Civil Appeals Nos. 652 of 1957 and 654 of 1957 are against the order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta declining to call for a statement of the case from the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta, under section 66  2  of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 651 of 1957 and 653 of 1957 are against the orders of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal holding that four firms belonged to the same group of persons and refusing to renew registration under section 26A.

anchor.surface_text: The remaining two, Civil Appeals Nos. 651 of 1957 and 653 of 1957, are against the orders of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal holding that the four firms, firm Ladhuram Taparia, Jagannath Hanumanbux, Jagannath Harnarain and Ganpatrai Jorawarmall belonged to the same group of persons, viz., Ladhuram Taparia and Ganpatrai Taparia and their respective sons, and that the income earned in the business in cloth and yarn carried on in those names was liable to be amalgamated for purposes of assessment in the hands of the appellant firm and refusing to renew registration of these firms under section 26A of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: There was originally a firm carrying on business in cloth and yarn in the name Jagannath Harnarain at 37, Armenian Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: There was originally a firm carrying on business in cloth and yarn in the name and style of Jagannath Harnarain at 37, Armenian Street, Calcutta.

facts.text: Original firm Jagannath Harnarain was dissolved sometime in the year 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Of this firm, Ladhuram, Ganpatrai and their brother and several outsiders were partners. On account of disputes between the partners, this firm was dissolved sometime in the year 1943.

facts.text: Deed of partnership for firm Ladhuram Taparia executed on October 16, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: In anticipation of dissolution of the firm or shortly thereafter, six firms were stated and separated deeds of partnership were executed in respect thereof. The deed of partnership in respect of firm Ladhuram Taparia was executed on October 16, 1941,

facts.text: Firm Ladhuram Taparia registered with Registrar of Firms on July 19, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: and the firm was registered with the Registrar of Firms on July 19, 1943.

facts.text: Firm Ladhuram Taparia commenced business on February 28, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The firm, it was claimed by the appellants, companymenced business on February 28, 1941, and companysisted of three partners, Ladhuram Taparia, Ganpatrai Taparia and Bhairodan Maheshwari.

facts.text: Firm Ladhuram Taparia partners: Ladhuram Taparia (8 annas), Ganpatrai Taparia (4 annas), Bhairodan Maheshwari (4 annas).

anchor.surface_text: The firm, it was claimed by the appellants, companymenced business on February 28, 1941, and companysisted of three partners, Ladhuram Taparia, Ganpatrai Taparia and Bhairodan Maheshwari. Firm Ladhuram Taparia was registered for purposes of income-tax under section 26A in the assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44 and 1944- 45.

facts.text: Firm Ladhuram Taparia registered under section 26A for assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: Firm Ladhuram Taparia was registered for purposes of income-tax under section 26A in the assessment years 1942-43, 1943-44 and 1944- 45.

facts.text: Six firms: Ladhuram Taparia, Jagannath Hanumanbux, Jagannath Harnarain, Ganpatrai Jorawarmall, Seth Ladhuram Taparia, Seth Ladhuram Taparia Co.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the firm of Ladhuram Taparia, the other five firms which came into existence for companyducting business in cloth and yarn were Jagannath Hanumanbux, Jagannath Harnarain, Ganpatrai Jorawarmall, Seth Ladhuram Taparia and Seth Ladhuram Taparia Co.

facts.text: Ladhuram and Ganpatrai are full brothers.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the partners of these firms, Ladhuram Ganpatrai are full brothers.

facts.text: Sovachand, partner of firm III, is son of Ganpatrai.

anchor.surface_text: Sovachand partner of firm No. III is the son of Ganpatrai.

facts.text: Hanumanbux and Ganeshmal are sons of Ladhuram.

anchor.surface_text: Hanumanbux partner of firms Nos. II and IV and Ganeshmal partners of firm No. III are the songs of Ladhuram.

facts.text: Certain partners are strangers to Taparia family: Bhairodan Maheshwari, Malchand Baid, Kanayalal Lohia, Rupnarain Gaggar, Chunilal Lakhotia, Kisenlal Karwa.

anchor.surface_text: Bhairodan Maheshwari partner in firm No. 1, Malchand Baid and Kanayalal Lohia partners in firm No. IV, Rupnarain Gaggar and Chunilal Lakhotia partners in firm No. V, and Kisenlal Karwa partner in firm No. VI, are strangers to the family of Taparias.

facts.text: Firms I, II, III, V registered under s26A before 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: In assessment proceedings before the assessment year I945-46, firm Nos. I, II, III and V were registered under section 26A of the Income-tax Act and tax was assessed on that footing.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer investigated status of six firms for 1945-46 after receiving information that they belonged to Ladhuram and Ganpatrai.

anchor.surface_text: Firms Nos. IV and VI submitted their returns for the first time for assessment of income-tax for the assessment year 1945-46. In the companyrse of the assessment proceedings, the Income-tax Officer  Central  Circle II, Calcutta, having received information that Ladhuram and his brother Ganpatrai has started diverse companycerns in different names and they had also started innumerable shops benami and that all these business belonged to Ladhuram and his brother Ganpatrai, started investigation into the status and ownership of the six firms.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held that firms I to VI belonged to one group: Ladhuram, Ganpatrai and sons; refused registration under s26A for 1945-46; amalgamated income in firm I.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, companycluded that all the same firms belonged to one and the same group of persons, namely, Ladhuram and his sons and Ganpatrai and the Ladhuram was the real man behind the scene and he played the principal part. The Income-tax Officer accordingly refused to register the firms under section 26A of Income-tax Act for the year of assessment 1945-46 and treated the aggregate income of the six firms as assessable in the hands of firm No. I.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed firms not genuine, belonged to group Ladhuram, Ganpatrai, sons; outsiders no interest; reduced income by Rs. 10,756.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Range C, Calcutta, agreed with the view of the Income-tax Officer that the partnership deeds were number genuine and were number intended to be acted upon and that the firms belonged to a group of person Ladhuram, Ganpatrai and their respective sons and the outsides had numberinterest in the business of the firm. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, however, reduced the assessable income by Rs. 10,756 but subject to that modification, dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Tribunal held firms I to IV belonged to Ladhuram, Ganpatrai, sons; outsiders nominal; amalgamated incomes I to VI in firm I, excluded Rs. 36,776 cash credits.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal against that order, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that firms Nos. I to IV only belonged to Ladhuram, his brother Ganpatrai and their respective sons, and that the outsiders in these firms were numberinally introduced in the firms with a view to lend a semblance of genuineness to the partnership deeds. ... The Tribunal accordingly held that incomes of firms I to VI were properly amalgamated in firm No. Is hands, but the Tribunal directed that out of the income of those firms, Rs. 36,776 be excluded.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Tribunal for reference under s66(1), Tribunal rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants applied to the Tribunal for a reference under section 66  1  of the Income-tax Act claiming that seventeen questions set out in an annexure to the petition arose out of the order of the Tribunal. ... The Tribunal having rejected this application holding that numberquestion of law arose out of their order,

facts.text: High Court rejected application to call for statement of case from Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants applied to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta that the Tribunal be called upon to submit a statement on those five questions. The High Court rejected this application summarily.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: ITO found firms financed each other, same outside financiers, inter sales/purchases, goods shifted between firms.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found that each of the firms had been companysiderably financed by the other firm. It is numbereworthy that almost the same outside parties had financed the aforesaid firms, namely, I to VI. On analysing the trading account of the various firms it is found that huge purchases have been made from and huge sales have been made to allied companycerns  excepting for firms Nos. V and VI which did handling of agency work under the Government of Bengal . It appears that the goods had been shifted from one companycern to another and only a divided portion of profits is actually shown by each of the firms.

facts.text: Businesses carried on nearly at same place, rent paid same dates, insured with same company.

anchor.surface_text: Other points of striking similarity, viz.,  a  the business of the firms had been carried on nearly at same place,  b  the rent register produced by the landlord of the premises showing that the rent register produced by the landlord of there premises showing that the rent of all the firms had been paid in most cases on the same date during the month,  c  goods had been insured with the same companypany, viz., Jupiter general Insurance Co. Ltd., are also numbericed.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in declining to call for a statement of the case from the Tribunal on the first three questions.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals with special leave counsel for the appellants conceded that the High Court was right in declining to call for a statement of the case from the Tribunal on the first three questions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel conceded; questions do not raise questions of law warranting reference under s66(2).

holdings.text: Question No. 2 does not raise any question of law.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that question No. 2 does not raise any question of law and question No. 1 was not raised before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inference on firm ownership from facts is finding of fact, not law.

holdings.text: Question No. 1 was not raised before the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that question No. 2 does not raise any question of law and question No. 1 was not raised before the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar; not pressed before Tribunal.

holdings.text: Because a partnership is registered under the Partnership Act, the income-tax authorities are not obliged to register it under section 26A.

anchor.surface_text: Again, because a partnership is registered under the partnership Act, the income-tax authorities are not obliged to register it under section 26A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: IT registration independent of Partnership Act registration; genuineness for tax purposes separate.

holdings.text: In refusing to admit the statements of accounts on the record of the appeal, any error of law was not committed.

anchor.surface_text: it cannot be said that in refusing to admit the statements on the record of the appeal, any error of law was committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statements derived from same books already examined; Tribunal could rely on originals.

holdings.text: The Tribunal considered arguments on quantum of taxable income; no question of law arises.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal took into consideration all the submissions of the assessee but came to the conclusion that no case had been made out for the Tribunals interference with the estimates of profit in the various concerns.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal referred to cash credits, inter se transactions, estimates under s13 proviso; found no ground to interfere.

holdings.text: Profits had to be estimated under the proviso to section 13; Tribunal adequately reasoned on quantum.

anchor.surface_text: It was clear that profits had in all these firms to be estimated under the proviso to section 13.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accounts unreliable; Tribunal reviewed ITO/AAC reasons, no interference warranted.

holdings.text: No question of law arises out of the Tribunal's decision on genuineness of firms and amalgamation of incomes.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the decision of the Tribunal on this points is concluded by findings of fact which are based on ample material on the record and no question of law arises out of this part of the order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Findings on same group, nominal outsiders, based on material like financing, inter-transactions, control.

holdings.text: The Tribunal considered the addition of Rs. 2,39,796; no substance in plea of inadequate reasoning; no question of law.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of the record, we do not think that there is a substance in the plea that the Tribunal had not considered the question whether the amount of Rs. 2,39,796 was properly added to the income of the appellants as undisclosed profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Benami concerns per ITO/AAC; no evidence of genuineness; Tribunal noted no ground to interfere.

holdings.text: No question of law arose out of the order of the Tribunal; High Court right.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court was right in holding that no question of law arose out of the order of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All aspects covered by findings of fact.

holdings.text: No case is made out justifying interference under Article 136 with the orders of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the view that no case is made out justifying interference in the appeals filed directly against the orders of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special leave appeals fail on merits; uphold refusal of s26A registration and amalgamation.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with costs.
